reviewText:
Tapping into that extraordinarily familiar ground that Clash of Clans first revolutionized, Battle Islands is a briefly entertaining if slow-burning freemium strategy game. It’s a little too familiar to truly warrant much excitement but those keen for a World War 2 themed title will find more enjoyment.

Set in 1942, players control a platoon of soldiers as they attempt to establish bases on various tropical islands in the South Pacific. While the theme is slightly different from the norm, the gameplay remains much the same.

A brief tutorial guides one through the basics, which mostly relate to placing buildings and training troops. A barrier keeps players protected from enemy attack for a few days in order to give them a chance to be more established, but this is easily circumvented by the bloodthirsty. Once the tutorial is out of the way, structure is offered through a series of challenges that can be completed with the bonus being that they offer up gold bricks.

Gold bricks are essential here given that they’re the premium currency that affects how quickly projects are completed, among other things. While Battle Islands might seem initially generous with the gold bricks, they vanish quite quickly – leaving one quite restricted due to the plethora of timers.

Waiting around for various tasks to complete will be a regular part of one’s sessions with Battle Islands. It’s really quite slow going. Competing with opposing players is briefly fun, but it’s nothing new for the genre and plays it very safe.

It’s the theme that makes Battle Islands slightly more noticeable, with the World War 2 theme often proving more endearing than something fantastical. That’s sufficient for a brief play session but I’d be surprised if anyone found the game truly gripping for any length of time. It’s not that it does anything particularly badly, it’s just all too familiar.

THIS GAME IS NOT A RTS!

I've spent several days and weeks playing this on the phone, then I saw this PC port, they were saying it was a real time strategy and making the trailer look as RTS-like as possible. Trust me, this is not an RTS. If anyone is familiar with the game Clash of Clans, we can all say that its not an RTS. This game is very much based off similar mechanics as CoC, timeconsuming, pay to get things faster etc. A RTS is when you build up your base and manage recources in a REAL TIME (current time) strategy game. Which means managing units, where the units go, managing buildings and how to defend them etc. This game offers no such thing as RTS. You go into a battle, you spawn your units, after they are spawned you have no control over them WHATSOEVER. This is not RTS.

The mobile verison is great and all, I actually love the mobile verison, but right off the bat I saw when I moved the camera, the game rendered wierdly and did some crazy fps drops. In general, I just put 10 minutes into this port and I saw several rendering issues and FPS drops when I try to move the screen.

It was a great mobile game, I still play it to this day, but the PC port was unnecessary and just another way to make money! Get the mobile verison, not this.

I like this game. I see a lot of reviews claiming it's pay-to-win, but I have over half the achievements now and I've yet to pay a dime (nor do I intend to).

It's not perfect, and I don't like the way it encourages you to buy gold (though I can understand why it does), but if you have patience it can be quite a bit of fun.

Oh, and it's free. Fun + Free is a hard combination to beat.

reviewText: This game is a lot of fun. It can be a little challenging (ok, a lot) with all the bully commanders and tyrants out there pummeling your humble defenses and farming away your hard earned crates. But, that's one of the reasons to like the game - the challenge and strategy required to preserve your stockpile long enough to advance to the next level and achievement. It can be a little disturbing when your supplies get taken away, especially just prior to the implementation of upgrading your units and defenses. I'd whine and cry a little more if I wasn't guilty of doing that to others myself - after all, it's WAR! And even the mighty lion and the fastest cheetah go for the weakest prey. Why fight someone your own size to risk great loss when you can pound a lesser army and take all the booty you want. Ever hear of Sun Tzu? It's a great game, loads fast, functional and free to play, The developers are happy to sell you gold at a fairly reasonable cost which can be used to purchase massive amounts of supplies. . .but where's the fun it that? Only a weak-minded, cowardly, punk-axx, spend-thrift little sissy/bully would need to do that. Also, it can be very helpful if you have the availability to log on for a couple minutes about every hour or so, but you can also go days and weeks without doing so and still find yourself in pretty good shape since no one can actually permanently destroy your base - you just lose crates and dog tags. Give it a try, it's cool. And, you can also draw really cool pictures of the islands and units in a makeshift birthday card to your girlfriend when you forget about her, add a quick rhyme and a clever poem about your gameplay and how it in no way compares to all her talent and beauty, and then she'll love you even more and appreciate all your efforts in the game while she's making dinner and cleaning up around the house. (She's smacking me in the back of the head right now - I gotta go) Play the game.

reviewText:
If you never played this game before you will probably dislike it like I did when I first started.  I didn't want to quit playing it on the first try so I played it for 2 or 3 days to see if it would hold my attention. I now play it on the IPAD, PC and PS4 on the daily basis because it's very entertaining once you understand the mechanics.

In short, you have to build your military might by attacking online rivals, completing battle campaigns, upgrading your factories, oil rigs and defending your resources from invasion.  The players  whom have the best offensive and defensive strategy rise quickly via upgrades, promotions and joint battle operations.

If you don't like waiting you have the option to buy gold bricks which allow you to avoid long waiting periods associated with crafting your offensive and defensive measures in order to engage in more intense battles. Gold is rewarded to all players after their meter reaches 100% and they move on to the next level so this is completely optional.

The game gets better as you progress and build a stronger military to handle both offensive and defensive measures. Eventually you will want to form an online alliance or create your own. This will allow you to team up against stronger rivals whom will grant you many more rewards if you are successful on the battlefield.

There are some frustrating issues with the games like tanks ignoring enemy fire even though you send in 5 tanks to handle business in the general area. Another issue is bunker soldiers shooting through buildings and destroying tanks and soldiers that are clearly at a safe distance behind a fortified wall ect ..

The artificial intelligence could be a bit better but overall it's still a fun game to play overtime.

reviewText:
Many say that this game is another money grabber a pay to win game & yes they are correct in saying that to a degree BUT they only get your money if you choose to give it to them & if you enjoy the game for what it is then you are basically not paying to win but playing to enjoy.

----- A Few Points -----

#1: The game has been labeled as a f2p so you choose weather or not to install & play it, you don't have a loaded gun against your head that's forcing you to do so, either play it or not its simple.

#2: I admit i have payed alittle of my own money to get an extra engineer & maybe a few quick upgrades but AGAIN thats players choice not the devs threatening your life if you dont,
but you do get a few free gold (microtransaction currency) by completing some in-game achievements which is nice.

#3: This game has its moments & i have no complaints with it being a f2p but mere suggestions on what may need improving, yes it has its in-game issues for a few players and they can be very upsetting but thats because its a video game not a painting by Leonardoda vinci (refering to it being perfect :p)

#4: This is a browser style kind of game that you progress through with the aid of real time, for example: The command bunker level  3 upgrade (level 3 unlocks a nice selection of units) will take 24hours in real time to complete, yes its quite a wait but when you leave the game to do its work and go off to play something else it has the next stage ready for you to use when/if you return which to be honest i like but could do with a slight tweek here and there.

----- Final Verdict -----

Battle Islands is a very fun small f2p game that has its moments and can be enjoyed by anyone, it may be a bit of a waiting game (literally) but can be played WITHOUT any microtransactions if one chooses.

Overall Score 8/10
